title: R41249
content: Prior to 1996, health insurance coverage for mental illness was historically less generous than for physical illnesses, with lower limits, fewer covered services, and increased cost sharing. Mental health parity laws aim to ensure that health insurance coverage for mental health services is equal to coverage for medical and surgical benefits. This includes removing lower dollar limits, increasing coverage for hospital days and outpatient visits, and reducing cost sharing disparities. Mental health parity laws aim to ensure equal insurance coverage for mental health services compared to medical and surgical benefits. Policymakers have developed approaches based on coverage mandates and parity requirements to achieve this goal. Parity laws may require insurers to cover certain mental illnesses, with different approaches such as mandated coverage and parity coverage.
